chapter.title: HTTP module
chapter.para: The HTTP module contains all the classes directly related to HTTP. This includes cookies, sessions and file upload handling. These classes encapsulate the $_COOKIE, $_SESSION and $_FILES superglobal arrays, respectively.

sect1.title: Cookies
sect1.para: Web:Extend provides a class that encapsulates the $_COOKIE array.
The cookie class can be used both as an application driver or standalone. This chapter will explain both ways.

sect2.title: With the application module
sect2.para: You can create and access the cookies object using the application module. To do so, simply call weeApp()->cookies.
By default the cookies object is created only when it is accessed. There is no overhead if you don't use it.
The cookies object acts much like the $_COOKIE array. You can access your variables like you would with an array:
By setting the value of cookies.path in the configuration file, you can change the path under which the cookies will be saved. By default the path used is the path to your bootstrap file (index.php).

sect2.para: If you are not using the application module, you can also create a standalone weeCookies object. Once created you can access your cookies exactly like you would with the $_COOKIE array. For example:
You can also define the path under which the cookies will be saved. By default the path used is the path to your bootstrap file (index.php).
All cookies set by this object will be saved under /path/to/my/app/.

sect2.para: You can set cookies in two different ways. The simpler way is to use weeCookies like an array. The following code will send the cookie my_str with a value of egg.
This way does not allow you to specify the expiration time however. If you need to, you can use the method set.

However these variables won't be available for this request. The cookies object do not store the variables you set: it sends them to the browser, which will send them back on the next request. So my_str won't be available until the next request.

sect2.title: Deleting cookies
sect2.para: To delete a cookie, simply unset it.
The value will be available in the object for the duration of the request. The cookie will be deleted by the browser upon reception of the response headers.

sect1.title: File upload
sect1.para: Two classes are designed to help you handle file uploads. These classes allow you to iterate through all the files, look for errors and safely move the files to their destination. The first class, weeUploads, wraps around the $_FILES array and allows you to retrieve files. The second class, weeUploadedFile, gives you a set of methods to manipulate the uploaded files.

sect2.title: Files and arrays of files
sect2.para: When you create an HTML file input widget, you need to give it a name that will be used to identify the file after the form is submitted. You can have either single or arrays of files. To receive only a single file, you do not need to do anything special. However if you want to receive an array of files all sharing the same name, you need to append [] to the name of all the HTML file input widgets that will upload files with a common name.
In this chapter, arrays of files refer to this specific use of HTML names.

sect2.title: Accessing a specific file
sect2.para: The class weeUploads provides methods to determine if a file has been uploaded and to retrieve it for later use. Note that even if a file has tentatively been uploaded, an error might have occurred and you still have to look for errors on the individual file.
Note that you can't use the method fetch on an array of files. However you can use the method exists on them.

sect2.title: Iterating through the uploaded files
sect2.para: You can iterate through all uploaded files using foreach.
You can also filter the files so that you would iterate only over a specific array of files using the method filter.

sect2.title: Error handling
sect2.para: Once you got your weeUploadedFile object, you need to check if the upload completed successfully. You can do so by using the method isOK. Then, if an error happened during the upload you can retrieve an error message using getError.

sect2.title: Retrieving file information
sect2.para: Once you know that the file was uploaded successfully, you can retrieve information about it. The weeUploadedFile object provides a few methods and properties that you can use.
Amongst them, of note are the getExt and getFilename methods. They allow you to retrieve the file extension and name, respectively.

sect2.title: Moving the uploaded file
sect2.para: You can use the method moveTo to move the uploaded file. Additionally you can use the method fileExists to determine whether a file already exists at the location where you want to move your uploaded file. They both use the same arguments, allowing you to reuse directly the values you would use for moveTo.
Note that if the second argument isn't provided the original filename will be used.

sect1.title: Sessions
sect1.para: Web:Extend contains a class that wraps the $_SESSION array, adding security checks to prevent attacks like session fixation.

The session classes can be used both as an application driver or standalone. This chapter describes both use, starting with the application driver way. Then you will learn how to store sessions in a table in your database.

sect2.title: With the application module
sect2.para:
weeApplication, the application module, can create a session automatically. You just have to change a line in the configuration file. Edit the parameter start.session and set it to 1 like this:
start.session = 1
The framework will then create a weeSession object, initiating a session, each time a page is requested. You can then access this object by typing weeApp()->session.

Autostarting the session isn't required though. You could very well leave start.session at 0 and access weeApp()->session only when needed. If you do need to autostart it you should also enable the output buffering, because the session will create a cookie that needs to be sent before any output happens.

sect3.para: The session will be closed and the data will be stored upon destruction of the session's object. This is automatically done when the script ends, but you might want to close the session before that. You can close it by simply unsetting the object:

sect2.title: Obtaining the user's IP address
sect2.para: Finally, weeSession also allows you to retrieve easily the user's IP address using the getIP method. Calling weeApp()->session->getIP() will return the IP address of the user. If the user is behind a proxy, it will be the forwarded IP address that will be returned, and not the proxy IP address.

sect2.title: Storing the session data in a database
sect2.para: By default the session data is stored on the filesystem, each session containing an individual file. You might prefer storing sessions in a database for various reasons. One reason could be to improve security by making sure nobody can access your application's session data. Another could be because you need a cluster of web servers all sharing the same session data.
You can use the weeSessionDbTable class in lieu of weeSession to store the session data in a database table. Its usage is the same but its creation requires two other parameters.
The db parameter specify the database driver object that will be used to store the session. If it is not given then the default database weeApp()->db will be used instead.

The table parameter defines the table in which the session data is stored. The following table definition can be used. You can customize the schema definition as you wish as long as you keep the column names unchanged.
